description: MailOnline Sport and a host of writers have been shortlisted for the SJA awards. MailOnline has 213m global monthly unique visitors to make it the world's most popular newspaper website.
title: Mail writers nominated for Sports Journalism Association awards with MailOnline Sport up for website of the year
title_page: Mail writers nominated for Sports Journalism Association awards with MailOnline Sport up for website of the year | Daily Mail Online
text:
MailOnline Sport and a host of writers have been shortlisted for the Sports Journalism Association awards.
MailOnline - which has 213 million global monthly unique visitors to make it the world's most popular newspaper website - is shortlisted for the Laureus Sports Website award, which it won at the 2014 ceremony.
Both Daily Mail chief sports writer Martin Samuel and Mail on Sunday chief sports writer Oliver Holt have been shortlisted for the sports feature writer award.
Martin Samuel (left) and Oliver Holt have been shortlisted for the sports feature writer award
Neil Ashton, Matt Lawton and Charles Sale have all be nominated for sports news reporter.
Mail on Sunday sports editor Alison Kervin and reporter Sam Cunningham have been shortlisted for scoop of the year.
Kervin interviewed Paul Radcliffe after she was wrongly accused of doping, while Cunningham exclusively revealed that Leyton Orient players had been forced to stay in a hotel for a week as a punishment.
Neil Ashton (left) and Matt Lawton have been nominated for sports news reporter
Charles Sale (left) and Jeff Powell are also in the running for SJA awards
Derek Lawrenson (golf) and Martha Kelner (athletics) are in the specialist correspondent category
Boxing correspondent Jeff Powell, golf correspondent Derek Lawrenson and athletics correspondent Martha Kelner have all be shortlisted for specialist correspondent.
Nick Harris - who has written extensively on FIFA corruption for the Mail on Sunday - is nominated for investigative sports reporter.
Paul Newman and Lawrence Booth are in the running for the cricket correspondent award.
Football reporter Jack Gaughan has been nominated for young sports writer for reporters under the age of 30.
Nick Harris and Alison Kervin will be hoping to walk away with an award at the end of February
We're well represented for the Cricket Correspondent award with Paul Newman (left) and Lawrence Booth
Jack Gaughan (left) is nominated for Young Sports Writer and Sam Cunningham for Scoop of the Year
The Daily Mail has been named Newspaper of the Year at the last two SJA awards nights, while Martin Samuel is the reigning sports writer of the year.
